reviewText:
Red Johnson’s Chronicles is a game very similar to games like Puzzle Agent and Professor Layton, although it has a more serious tone and puzzles require a bit more effort than just pure logic. In fact, it blends together some of the better elements found in other (point-and-click) adventures games and does this successfully, but ultimately (and as expected) not without any flaws.

Red Johnson is a private investigator who’s investigating a murder at Drownedman’s Bridge. One clue leads to another and before you know it, you’re in the middle of it. The story is actually pretty cliché, and the final payoff isn’t as good as it should be. Furthermore, the game ends with a cliffhanger, one that wasn’t even necessary to begin with, in my opinion. Still, we got a part two because of it, because Chronicles is not just one game, but two. So you get two games for the price of one. Well, two chapters is more like it, but come on, that is a good deal.
But let’s not get ahead of ourselves and let’s just focus on the gameplay for a minute. You view the world from a fixed (first person) perspective and with your mouse you can click on points of interest. Some of these are useless (thankfully, there aren’t so many of these) and others are useful. The useful ones will usually zoom in on the object and let you solve a puzzle, or puzzles, next.
Puzzles range from slide puzzles and ‘detail’ puzzles (rotating an object in search of a clue, item or answer) to character confrontations where you have to pick the right answer.
Solving puzzles will earn you money and this money can later be used if you don’t know how to finish one. Hints are relatively cheap to buy so you could get through the game by just using one of the many, many hints. It clearly needed a bit of tweaking in that area.
There’s actually a good variety of puzzles here. Unfortunately, the game doesn’t always use checkpoints. Sometimes it does, but sometimes it doesn’t and when the latter happens you have to start the puzzle all over again. This is awkward game design and something that shouldn’t have happened to begin with. Some of the puzzles are tediously boring or hard to solve and if you have to quit because of a lack of time or because you don’t feel like playing it anymore you shouldn’t punish the player for this. Same goes for quitting the game while trying to solve a puzzle; the game registers it as one attempt if you quit halfway through.
Sometimes puzzles reward you with evidence and that evidence can be analyzed and compared by a device set up at your headquarters. These results can then be used to progress even further, by finding new suspects and places to go to, or interrogating suspects.
Every now and then a QTE will trigger and it’s because of the cool controls that these encounters become even remotely interesting in the first place. The mouse is used to create a motion so let’s say that you have some screws you need to get rid of then you have to rotate the mouse in a circular motion to unscrew them. During encounters the game will ask you to press the left button and move up, down, or anywhere else depending on the given situation. But, yes (there’s always a but), the controls just don’t work. I’ve failed many encounters because the game didn’t register them properly. Unnecessary and evil, because the game ranks you based on the number of tries it took you to finish an event or puzzle.
While you’re not doing any of the things mentioned above you have to search apartments and areas for clues. Unfortunately, some of the objects you have to search for are too hard to see because the graphics are either too dark or because the object isn’t instantly visible to you because it’s tucked away in a corner. So in the end it comes down to pixel hunting and that’s again something that shouldn’t be needed in this game, although it’s something we see often in the point-and-click genre.
The story is the usual ’whodunnit’ and even though it’s cliché, it’s executed pretty well. The characters all have the right motivations and the whole thing connects together nicely in the end.

The graphics consists of static backgrounds mixed with some small animations but on the PC they’re fuzzy and blurry and anything by hi-res. They’re also mostly brownish but that’s just the style of the game. Character animations are fine, but never great, and they’re also a bit unsharp. Lip syncing doesn’t seem to be there, characters just start moving their lips as soon as you enter a conversation.
Overall, the style of the game is pretty good, but it could’ve used some improvements here and there.
The voice acting is actually pretty good (which surprised me) and same goes for the jazzy music.

The game is pretty long. I think it will take anywhere between 4 or 6 hours to complete the first chapter and after that you still have chapter 2 to complete. My estimate is that it’s roughly the same length; I still have to finish it. But it’s good value for your money. You get a good amount of gameplay here.

Red Johnson’s Chronicles isn’t the game I hoped it would be. I expected another Professor Layton/Puzzle agent type of game, but got a regular point-and-click adventure instead. It mixes some fine gameplay elements found in other adventure games, and although that doesn’t make the game awesome or great it’s still become a somewhat enjoyable game in the end.

[Rating: 64/100]

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game but I just couldn't play it. The controls are horrible. Its a point and click game without the pointing and clicking because they force you to use keyboard controls for things that could easily, and much more fluently, be done with the mouse. At many points the mouse just did not work which seemed to be because i had the mouse at the wrong point on the screen. However since I didn't have a mouse pointer present at the time it was impossible to tell this.

There is also a very limited option screen which only features volume controls. There are no resolution or graphic options at all so you have to play on the settings they give you.

However if you can deal with these issues the game does have some redeeming factors. Although I didn't play long enough to see much of it the story did look to be interesting. The characters were designed very well and had great voices work. But the best factor about this game was the graphics style. The settings all looked amazing with vibrant colours.

Overall if you can overlook the horrible controls and other issues then you could play this game, if it was even just for the story. However I can't recommend this due to it being impossible to play for me personally.

TheIronicGamers rating system Don't ever buy this game.
Maybe consider it on a sale.
An average game.
A good game that should definitely be considered.
A must play!

reviewText: Cool noir atmosphere, music, world remind me of The Longest Journey. Awesome characters, voice acting is one of the best in video games. Red Johnson is so hot! QTEs are horribly implemented: you must use your mouse to perform various movements and that don't work most of the times.\nGameplay is very repetitive and puzzles are too difficult. I hope if the third part will be released then it will be more close to classic adventure than to collection of ♥♥♥♥ing hard puzzles which make me insane.

reviewText: Visually nicepuzzle game that looks like it could be great if not for the shockingly bad user interface. The controls are arbitrary, change without warning form one are to the next, and are never fully explained.\n\nIf you have the patience to put up with the UI, you may enjoy this. Otherwise, don't bother.

reviewText:
First I wanted to like this game just cause of its setting and some of its characters...in the end ...let's say: I felt a lot of vicarious embarrassment....

This game is an in many ways miserable attempt to combine two mostly similar but still different genres - point and click adventure and HOPA. It forces you to control itself through a nearly sadistic combination of keyboard and mouse and features a lot of stupid super high tech apparatuses. It's mostly non-dubbed, dubbed dialogues are only shown in weird out of place close-up scenes.

Positive points are some innovative ideas and somehow interesting puzzles (disassemble stuff, do a weird puzzle, get your clue), a not so bad dubbing and an impressive soundtrack.


It's also not clear which audience is targeted...(neither HOPA players nor point and click adventure player)
i liked it, its a shame they never got to the thirdpart

Jesus the interface and controls are some of the worst ive ever used. That's saying alot for a point n click n keyboard keys at random times game. The GFX and dialogue and everything is fine, but its just so clunky and obtuse to play.\n\nCase in point: I just deleted this because the QTE with Sonia doesnt work, she shoots you everytime.

Red Johnson's Chronicles is a point-and-click adventure that has a certain attitude, with decent graphics and some quick time events (i.e. press button X before time runs out, and then some other button, and then some other mouse move...) to pass the challenges"
